269O.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Neural Circuits for Sensory Processing and Behavior
269O.description: Microcircuitry of the cerebral cortex that underlies sensory processing and adaptive behavior.

269I.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Stem Cells and Gene Therapy in the Nervous System
269I.description:
The basic investigation of neural differentiation of stem cells, as well as the
use of stem cells and gene delivery for neuroregeneration.

239U.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: The Cytoskeleton and Morphogenesis
239U.description: Review of current literature and discussion of current research.

219X.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Cell Surface Glycoconjugate Interactions
219X.description: Investigations of cell surface glycoproteins as mediators of cell-cell interactions. Development of new methods for engineering cell surface structures.

218J.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Advanced 20th Century Perspectives on Cancer Cell Genetics
218J.description: Transduction of cellular sequences and genetic regulation of transformation by oncogenic retroviruses as models for natural carcinogenesis, including a critical review of the current research.

249L.title: Imaging Single Molecules: Fashion or Game Changer?
249L.description:
Research review in genetics, genomics and development.  We will explore how the detection of single particles
(DNA, RNA, proteins) can help with understanding cellular organization and
enzymatic processes dynamics and kinetics. Most of the experiments
described will be drawn from the gene expression and nuclear organization
literature.

269J.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Taste Recognition in Drosophila
269J.description: The molecular and cellular basis of taste perception in the model organism <Drosophila melanogaster>.

C100A.title: Biophysical Chemistry: Physical Principles and the Molecules of Life

102.title: Survey of the Principles of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
102.description: A comprehensive survey of the fundamentals of biological chemistry, including the properties of intermediary metabolites, the structure and function of biological macromolecules, the logic of metabolic pathways (both degradative and biosynthetic) and the molecular basis of genetics and gene expression.

293A.title: Research Seminar
293A.description: Seminar on presentation and evaluation of results in area of student's individual research interests.

166.title: Biophysical Neurobiology
166.description: Electrochemistry and ion transport phenomena, equivalent circuits, excitability, action potentials, voltage clamp and the Hodgkin-Huxley model.  Biophysical properties of ion channels.  Statistical and electrophysiological models of synaptic transmission, Quantitative models for dendritic structure and neuronal morphogenesis.  Sensory transduction, cellular networks as computational devices, information processing and transfer.

269F.title: Optogenetic Dissection of Neural Circuits
269F.description: Research review in neurobiology. Review of recent optogenetic strategies for dissecting neural connectivity, function, and dysfunction in the rodent and primate brain.

249D.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Mechanisms of Genetic Regulation in Yeast
249D.description: Genes, gene products and molecular mechanisms that control cell types in the unicellular eukaryote <Saccharomyces cerevisiae>.

481C.title: Instrumentation in Molecular and Cell Biology: Scanning Electron Microscopy

249S.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Evolution of Development Mechanisms
249S.description: Evolution of development mechanisms with a focus on the genes that regulate segmentation and regionalization of the body plan.

218K.title: Gene Editing for Fundamental Biology and Therapeutics
218K.description: The use of genome engineering to study cellular signaling (especially ubiquitin-mediated signals) and develop potential new therapeutics and diagnostics will be covered in research reports and reviews of the current literature and in discussion of current experiments in the field.

219B.title: Regulation of Translation
219B.description: Understanding the molecular basis and physiological role of translational regulation in gene expression with an emphasis on global profiling and functional genomics.

239Z.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Chromosome Remodeling and Reorganization During Meiosis
239Z.description: How chromosomes are reorganized during melosis to accomplish the pairing, recombinatin, and segregation leading up to successful gamete production.

249G.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Developmental and Evolutionary Genetics
249G.description: We study how genes control pattern formation during development and pattern modification during evolution.

32.title: Introduction to Human Physiology
32.description: A comprehensive introduction to human biology. The course will concentrate on basic mechanisms underlying human life processes, including cells and membranes; nerve and muscle function; cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and gastrointestinal physiology; metabolism, endocrinology, and reproduction.

269S.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Molecular Mechanisms of  Olfaction
269S.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

218S.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Cryo-Electron Microscopy of Macromolecules
218S.description: Structure-function studies of the cytoskeleton and large molecular machines by cryo-electron microscopy and image reconstruction.

200A.title: Fundamentals of Molecular and Cell Biology
200A.description: The goal of this course is to provide graduate-level instruction on molecular and cellular biosciences from a highly-integrated systems perspective, rather than using a more classic, techniques-oriented format. A collection of approaches, and a focus on critical thinking and problem solving, will be used to show how fundamental, highly-significant biological problems are "cracked open." Reading will be assigned from a mix of classic and current peer-reviewed papers selected by the instructors.

239W.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Leech Embryology and Development
239W.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

104.title: Genetics, Genomics, and Cell Biology
104.description: This course will introduce students to key concepts in genetic analysis, eukaryotic cell biology, and state-of-the-art approaches in genomic medicine. Lectures will highlight basic knowledge of cellular processes with the basis for human diseases, particularly cancer. Prerequisite courses will have introduced students to the concepts of cells, the central dogma of molecular biology, and gene regulation. Emphasis in this course will be on eukaryotic cell processes, including cellular organization, dynamics, and signaling.

236.title: Advanced Mammalian Physiology
236.description: Principles of mammalian (primarily human) physiology emphasizing physical, chemical, molecular, and cellular bases of functional biology. The following topics will be covered: cellular and membrane ion and nonelectrolyte transport; cell and endocrine regulation; autonomic nervous system regulation; skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscle; cardiovascular physiology; respiration; renal physiology; gastrointestinal physiology. Discussion section will study advanced physiological topics, including: presentations by the faculty; problem sets; discussion of the primary literature and of reviews; two presentations by each student on topics in current physiological research.

239KK.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Assembly and Subcellular Organization of Bacterial Organelles
239KK.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

218F.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Energy-dependent Proteases and Molecular Machines
218F.description: Our goals are to decipher the fundamental principles that govern substrate engagement, de-ubiquitylation, unfolding, and translocation by the proteasome.

150L.title: Immunology Laboratory
150L.description: Experimental techniques in mammalian molecular biology and cellular immunology. Molecular techniques covered include PCR and recombinant DNA procedures such as gene cloning, gene transfer, DNA sequencing, Southern blot, and restriction mapping. Immunological techniques covered include cell culture and monoclonal antibody production, flow cytometry, ELISA, immunoprecipitation, and western blot.

239J.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Steroid Hormone and Growth Factor Action
239J.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

239B.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Regulation of the Cell Cycle
239B.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

219Z.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Telomere Synthesis and Dynamics
219Z.description: Emphasizes a study of the replication of eukaryotic telomeric DNA. Special focus on techniques in protein biochemistry and molecular biology.

249V.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Induction in Vertebrate Development and ES Cell Differentiation
249V.description: The Roelink laboratory is interested in the mechanisms of embryonic induction, the phenomenon in which a group of cells changes the developmental fate of neighboring cells via the release of inducers.

239C.title: The Regulation of Meiotic Gene Expression and Cellular Morphogenesis
239C.description: The mechanisms that link cellular differentiation programs and dynamic gene regulation in complex eukaryotic systems remain mysterious. Such programs drive diverse and central biological processes including organismal development, immune function, disease progression, and meiosis. This course is focused on the molecular basis for the cellular remodeling accompanying meiosis, the highly conserved process by which gametes are produced.

55.title: Plagues and Pandemics
55.description: Discussion of how infectious agents cause disease and impact society at large. We will examine historical and current examples of plagues and pandemics and consider the question of what we should do to ameliorate the impact of infectious disease in the future. The course is intended for non-majors and will begin by briefly providing necessary background in microbiology and immunology. The primary focus in each subsequent week, however, will be on discussing a particular infectious disease. The course will be broad in scope covering biological, historical, ethical and social implications of each disease.

239I.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Cytoskeleton and Cell Motility
239I.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

239BB.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Mechanics and Dynamics of Cell Movements
239BB.description: Research in our laboratory is focused on the mechanics and dynamics of cell movements on the purified protein, single cell, and tissue levels. For these studies, we are developing new instruments to quantify cell and molecular mechanics bases on optical microscopy, force microscopy, and microfabrication.

249F.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Neuronal Development
249F.description: Molecular and genetic approaches to the problem of how neurons develop, with emphasis on <Drosophila melanogaster> and <Caenorhabditis elegans>.

481B.title: Instrumentation in Molecular and Cell Biology: Transmission Electron Microscopy

292.title: Research
292.description: Individual research under the supervision of a faculty member.

249M.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Saccharomyces Cerevisiae Microtubule Cytoskeleton
249M.description: Review of current literature and discussion of current research.

132.title: Biology of Human Cancer
132.description: The course is designed for students interested in learning about the molecular and cell biology of cancer and how this knowledge is being applied to the prevention, diagnosis and therapy of cancer. Topics covered include tumor pathology and epidemiology; tumor viruses and oncogenes; intracellular signaling; tumor suppressors; multi-step carcinogenesis and tumor progression; genetic instability in cancer; tumor-host interactions; invasion and metastasis; tumor immunology; cancer therapy.

219U.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Single Molecule Biophysics
219U.description: Methods of single molecule manipulation and visualization that are used to characterize the structure and mechanochemical properties of translocating DNA binding protein such as RNA polymerase and to investigate the mechanical denaturation of single protein molecules will be covered in research reports and reviews of the current literature and in discussion of current experiments in the field.

239T.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: The Cell Biology of Fertilization
239T.description: Research in our lab is focused on the cell biology of mammalian fertilization. Our lab uses biophysical, biochemical, and molecular genetics methods to study sperm ion channels and transporters that regulate sperm motility, chemotaxis, and the acrosome reaction. A better understanding of these processes will eventually lead to the development of effective tools to control and preserve male fertility, improve the reproductive health of human population worldwide, and advance family planning.

200B.title: Fundamentals of Molecular and Cell Biology
200B.description: The goal of this course is to provide graduate-level instruction on molecular and cellular biosciences from a highly-integrated systems perspective, rather than using a more classic, techniques-oriented format. A collection of approaches, and a focus on critical thinking and problem solving, will be used to show how fundamental, highly-significant biological problems are "cracked open." Reading will be assigned from a mix of classic and current peer-reviewed papers selected by the instructors.

259G.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: T Cell Development
259G.description: Molecular and cellular aspects of thymocyte differentiation.

269T.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Processing of Visual Information in the Mammalian Brain
269T.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

218O.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Chemical Biology and Enzymology
218O.description: Topics at the interface of chemistry and biology with a particular focus on mechanisms of enzyme catalysis.

135A.title: Topics in Cell and Developmental Biology: Molecular Endocrinology
135A.description: Molecular mechanisms by which hormones elicit specific responses and regulate gene expression; hormone-receptor interaction; synthesis, transport and targeting of hormones, growth factors and receptors.

249J.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Developmental and Molecular Genetics of <C. elegans>
249J.description: Molecular and genetical analysis of sex determination and dosage compensation in the nematode <C. elegans>.

219F.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Eukaryotic Gene Expression
219F.description: Protein-DNA interactions and the control of gene expression in eukaryotes.

239M.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: MicroRNA Functions in Cancer Development, Mouse Tumor Models
239M.description: Malignant transformation represents the endpoint of successive genetic lesions that confer uncontrolled proliferation and survival, unlimited replicative potential, and invasive growth.

219J.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Structure and Function of RNA
219J.description: RNA structure, folding, and function. Specific topics include ribozyme mechanisms, RNA-mediated translation initiation, and protein targeting and secretion.

290.title: Graduate Seminar
290.description: Graduate student presentations on selected research topics in molecular and cell biology. Several sections covering different topics offered each semester. Concurrent enrollment in more than one section is permitted. List of topics to be announced before each semester.

259B.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Specificity of T Lymphocytes
259B.description: Mechanisms of immune surveillance by T lymphocytes.

219Y.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Regulation of HIV Gene Expression
219Y.description: Regulation of HIV gene expression by viral proteins and cellular cofactors will be covered in research reports and reviews of the current literature and in discussion of current experiments in the field.

150.title: Molecular Immunology
150.description: Fundamentals of immunology with emphasis on biochemical and molecular approaches to study of the immune system and its application in medicine and biotechnology. Topics covered include description of the immune system, antibody and T-cell receptor structure and function, genes of the immunoglobulin superfamily, cells and molecular mediators that regulate the immune response, allergy, autoimmunity, immunodeficiency, tissue and organ transplants, and tumor immunology.

251.title: The Regulation of Immune System Development and Function
251.description: This is an advanced seminar course which will consider current research questions and experimental approaches in molecular and cellular immunology. Each registrant will present a 30-minute research talk describing the problems they are studying, the approach they are taking, their preliminary data, and technical problems. Other course participants (including basic immunology faculty) will provide criticism and suggestions.

269U.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Diseases/Retina
269U.description: Evaluation of current research in molecular mechanisms underlying diseases of the retina.

239EE.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Cell Morphogenesis
239EE.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

218Z.title: Molecular and Cellular Mechanisms of Nutrient Sensing
218Z.description: In our laboratory, we study the molecular mechanisms of nutrient sensing and growth control.  Specific areas of interest include the mTOR pathway, energy sensing, lysosomal biology and translational control.

C62.title: Drugs and the Brain
C62.description: The history, chemical nature, botanical origins, and effects on the human brain and behavior of drugs such as stimulants, depressants, psychedelics, analgesics, antidepressants, antipsychotics, steroids, and other psychoactive substances of both natural and synthetic origin. The necessary biological, chemical, and psychological background material for understanding the content of this course will be contained within the course itself.

249T.title: Research Review in Genetics, Genomics and Development: Evolution of Genomes
249T.description: Comparative analysis of eukaryotic genomes to inform the origins and diversification of animals and plants.

163L.title: Mammalian Neuroanatomy Lab
163L.description: Development, structure (gross and microscopic), and functional relationships of the mammalian nervous system.

C116.title: Microbial Diversity
C116.description: This course for upper-division and graduate students will broadly survey myriad types of microbial organisms, both procaryote and eucaryote, using a phylogenetic framework to organize the concept of "biodiversity." Emphasis will be on the evolutionary development of the many biochemical themes, how they mold our biosphere, and the organisms that affect the global biochemistry. Molecular mechanisms that occur in different lineages will be compared and contrasted to illustrate fundamental biological strategies. Graduate students additionally should enroll in C216, Microbial Diversity Workshop.

219T.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Signal Transduction Mechanisms
219T.description: Discussion of recent research on various aspects of signal transduction mechanisms in eukaryotic cells, including G protein-coupled receptors, protein kinase cascades, synthesis and mobilization of lipid mediators, calcium sensing and response pathways, activation and inhibition of gene expression, and the biochemical basis of signal desensitization and physiological adaptation, with strong emphasis on genetic and molecular analysis of these systems, especially in the yeast <Saccharomyces cerevisiae.>

269R.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Potassium Channels and Synaptic Plasticity
269R.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

133L.title: Physiology and Cell Biology Laboratory
133L.description: Experimental analyses of central problems in cell biology and physiology using modern techniques, including DNA cloning and protein biochemistry, fluorescence microscopy of the cytoskeleton and organelles, DNA transfection and cell cycle analysis of cultured mammalian cells, RNA interference and drug treatments to analyze ion channel function in cell contractility and intracellular signaling, and somatosensation.

239V.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Molecular Mechanisms of Transduction in Touch and Pain Receptors
239V.description: Review of current literature and discussion of current research. Current research focuses on elucidating the molecular mechanisms of somatosensory mechanotransduction.

90D.title: Freshman Seminars: Immunology
90D.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley Seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester.

90D.title: Freshman Seminars: Immunology
90D.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley Seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester.

259N.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Immunology, Microbiology, and Genetics of Bacterial Pathogenesis
259N.description: Role of innate host responses in defense against intracellular bacterial pathogens.

90E.title: Freshman Seminars: Neurobiology
90E.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley Seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester.

249K.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Animal Origins
249K.description: Evaluation of current research on choanoflagellates, sponges, and animal origins. Intended to complement ongoing research for graduate students.

32L.title: Introduction to Human Physiology Laboratory
32L.description: Experiments and demonstrations are designed to amplify and reinforce information presented in 32. Exercises include investigations into the structure and function of muscle, nerve, cardiovascular, renal, respiratory, endocrine, and blood systems.

C216.title: Microbial Diversity Workshop
C216.description: This workshop for graduate students will parallel C116, Microbial Diversity, which should be taken concurrently. Emphasis in the workshop will be on review of research literature and formulation of paper pertinent to research in microbial diversity.

259E.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Regulation of T Cell Receptor Genes Expression
259E.description: Molecular biology of T cell receptor genes and their transcription controlling proteins/genes. Programmed cell death during thymocyte differentiation.

249N.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Gene Regulation
249N.description: Current literature and research in gene regulation will be covered in research reports and reviews of the current literature and in discussion of current experiments in the field.

219G.title: Virus-Host Interactions
219G.description: Understanding the creative strategies viruses use to manipulate gene expression in host cells, with a focus on RNA-based regulation of gene expression.

239FF.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Signal Transduction and Tumor Suppressor Genes
239FF.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

219H.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Molecular and Cell Biology of <Listeria monocytogenes> Pathogenesis
219H.description: Discussion of recent research on the genetics, cell biology, and immunology of the model facultative intracellular bacterical pathogen, <Listeria monocytogenes.>

249BB.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Aging and Protein Homeostasis
249BB.description: Central to the aging process is the unfolding of the proteome. Specific areas under study include cellular responses to protein misfolding and coordination of these responses across an organism.

218R.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: The Protein Folding Problem
218R.description: Protein structure, stability, design, and the pathway of protein folding.

259C.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Nuclear Receptor-Mediated Regulation of Neuroinflammation
259C.description: In this course we will discuss our research as well as recent literatures focusing on understanding of 1) How is homeostasis in the CNS regulated by innate immune functions of microglia? 2) How can we intervene in dysfunction of microglia-mediated immune functions using NRs signaling and transcription?

218D.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Gene Regulation at the RNA Level
218D.description: RNA elements involved in alternative splicing and other co-transcriptional mechanisms of regulation. Specific areas of interest include riboswitches and other structured RNA elements involved in gene regulation.

C110L.title: General Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Laboratory
C110L.description: Experimental techniques of biochemistry and molecular biology, designed to accompany the lectures in Molecular and Cell Biology 100B and 110.

259J.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Immune Evasion by Viruses
259J.description: The mechanisms used by viruses to counteract the pressure of the immune system.

218Q.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Single Molecular Imaging of Macromolecular Enzymes
218Q.description: Yildiz laboratory combines molecular biology and single molecule biophysical techniques to understand mechanisms that underlie cellular organization and motility. Specific focuses of the lab are to dissect 1) the mechanism of cytoplasmic dynein motility, 2) the regulation of intraflagellar transport, and 3) the protection and maintenance of mammalian telomeres.

269C.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Molecular Mechanisms of Neuronal Plasticity
269C.description: Research in our laboratory focuses on understanding how neurons use biochemical pathways to integrate diverse types of information in order to adjust synaptic strength and modulate neuronal excitability, and how these interactions go awry in disease.  To investigate this we are taking a multi-disciplinary approach incorporating molecular, biochemical, imaging, and electrophysiological analyses in mouse and human cells.

291A.title: Introduction to Research
291A.description: Closely supervised experimental work under the direction of an individual faculty member; an introduction to experimental methods and research approaches in particular areas of molecular and cell biology.

239R.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Telomere Biology of Human Stem Cells
239R.description: The goal of our laboratory is to understand the key functions of telomeres and telomerase in tissue homeostasis, tumorigenesis, and aging. To this end, we generate genetically engineered human pluripotent and adult stem cell models to measure telomere and telomerase function during cellular differentiation and tumor formation.

249Y.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Mechanisms of Gene Control in Vertebrate Animals
249Y.description: This course will focus on mechanisms of gene control in vertebrate animals, particularly in the area of vertebrate development. Amphibian egg formation, mesoderm induction, neural induction, and patterning of the nervous system at the molecular level. Control of transcription, post-transcriptional control of gene expression (including control of RNA turnover and RNA localization).

259D.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Mycobacterial Biology and Host-Pathogen Interactions
259D.description:
We will discuss macrophage biology and innate immunity in the context of infection with *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* through
discussion of current research from the Stanley Lab and both cutting edge and classic literature in relevant fields.

269D.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Signaling Within and Between Neurons
269D.description: Review of recent research in molecular mechanisms involved in intracellular and extracellular signaling in the nervous system.

218P.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Chemical Biology and Neuroscience
218P.description: Molecular approaches to designing and deploying tools for voltage imaging and brain mapping.

259F.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Natural Killer (NK) Cell and T Cell Receptors
259F.description: Molecular and biological basis for recognition by natural killer cells and T cells.

249X.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Comparative Genomics and Computational Biology
249X.description: The fundamental problem of comparative genomics: the determination of the origins and evolutionary history of the nucleotides in all extant genomes. My work incorporates various aspects of genomics, including the reconstruction of ancestral genomes (paleogenomics), the modeling of genome dynamics (phylogenomics and systems biology), and the assignment of function of genome elements (functional genomics and epigenomics).

249Q.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Computational Genomics
249Q.description: Recent developments in computational methods for genomics and their application for understanding the structure and function of genes encoded in completely sequenced genomes.

269B.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Synaptic Transmission and Neuromodulation
269B.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

269M.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Insect Neurophysiology
269M.description: Drosophila mutants that have behavioral abnormalities to unravel new and basic features of nervous system structure and function.

249C.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Nucleic Acid-Protein Interactions and Control of Gene Expression
249C.description: Biochemical and molecular genetic aspects of eukaryotic messenger RNA splicing and transposition, with an emphasis on <Drosophila melanogaster> as an experimental system.

218H.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Protein Synthesis in Bacteria and Mammals
218H.description: The mechanism of protein synthesis in bacteria and human cells. Specific areas of interest include the structure and function of the ribosome and the regulation of protein synthesis.

269W.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Neural Activity Affecting the Assembly of Neural Circuits
269W.description: How neural activity affects the assembly of neural circuits.

249H.title: Investigating Cellular Aging and Chromosome Segregation during Gametogenesis
249H.description: This course focuses on understanding  1) how cellular aging is affected during gametogenesis, the developmental program that produces gametes for sexual reproduction and 2) how chromosome segregation is regulated during meiosis, the specialized cell division that generates gametes.

218E.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Viruses as Models for Eukaryote Gene Expression and Replication
218E.description: Recent developments in eukaryote viral and cellular regulation. New concepts in transcription and RNA replication, with particular emphasis on virus-cell interactions.

C261.title: Cellular and Developmental Neurobiology
C261.description: This course covers the molecular/cellular basis of neuron excitability (membrane potentials, action potential generation and propagation, ion channels), synaptic transmission and plasticity, sensory receptor function, and developmental neurobiology.

239Q.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Regulation of Cell Polarity in Drosophila
239Q.description: Mechanisms underlying the establishment and maintenance of cellular organization in epithelia and other cell types.

90B.title: Freshman Seminars: Cell and Developmental Biology
90B.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley Seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester.

249Z.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Chromosome Structure and Integrity, Genome Evolution
249Z.description: Use of genetic, cell biological, and biochemical approaches in budding yeast to understand genome integrity, genome evolution, and most recently desiccation tolerance.

218I.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Chemical Biology and Inorganic Chemistry
218I.description: Research and literature topics in chemical biology and inorganic chemistry relevant to human health and disease and energy science will be discussed.

110.title: Molecular Biology: Macromolecular Synthesis and Cellular Function
110.description: Molecular biology of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells and their viruses. Mechanisms of DNA replication, transcription, translation. Structure of genes and chromosomes. Regulation of gene expression. Biochemical processes and principles in membrane structure and function, intracellular trafficking and subcellular compartmentation, cytoskeletal architecture, nucleocytoplasmic transport, signal transduction mechanisms, and cell cycle control.

269H.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Recent Advances in Retinal Neurobiology
269H.description: Review of current literature and discussion of original research.

136.title: Physiology
136.description: Principles of mammalian (primarily human) physiology emphasizing physical, chemical, molecular and cellular bases of functional biology. The following topics will be covered: cellular and membrane ion and nonelectrolyte transport; cell and endocrine regulation; autonomic nervous system regulation; skeletal, smooth and cardiac muscle; cardiovascular physiology; respiration; renal physiology; gastrointestinal physiology. Discussion section led by Graduate Student Instructor will review material covered in lecture.

269Q.title: Research Review in Neurobiology: Sensory Processing and Plasticity in Cerebral Cortex
269Q.description: How the cerebral cortex processes sensory input and stores information about the sensory world. We focus on the rat's primary somatosensory (S1) cortex.

118.title: The Cancer Karyotype: What it is and What it Does
118.description: Mutational cancer theories do not explain why cancers: 1) have clonal individual karyotypes; 2) have polygenic transcriptomes and phenotypes; 3) have flexible karyotypes, which evolve progressive malignancy and drug resistance, but maintain autonomy and even immortality; and 4) Why carcinogens induce cancer only after conspicuously long latent periods of years to decades. To answer these questions, this course tests a new karyotypic theory, which postulates that cancers evolve much like new species.

218W.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Enzyme Catalysis
218W.description: Fundamental aspects of enzyme catalysis, as probed by kinetic, spectroscopic, and molecular biological approaches.

239HH.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Mechanisms of Control of Growth and Cell Proliferation
239HH.description: Identifying pathways that restrict growth and cell proliferation in vivo.

140.title: General Genetics
140.description: In-depth introduction to genetics, including mechanisms of inheritance; gene transmission and recombination; transposable DNA elements; gene structure, function, and regulation; and developmental genetics. Some exams may be given in the evening.

249MM.title: Physical Biology of Living Organisms
249MM.description:
Research review in genetics, genomics and development.  In development a single cell goes through a series of repeated divisions
and these cells read the program encoded in their DNA in order to become
familiar cell types such as those found in muscle, liver, or our brains. The
goal of our lab is to uncover the rules behind these decisions with the
objective of predicting and manipulating developmental programs from just
looking at DNA sequence. In order to reach this predictive understanding we
combine physics, synthetic biology, and new technologies to query and
control developmental decisions in real time at the single cell level in
the fruit fly embryo.

219A.title: Structural Membrane Biology
219A.description: The mechanisms by which protein complexes use their structures to bud, bend, and sever membranes will be covered in research reports and reviews of the current literature and in discussion of current experiments in the field.

218A.title: Mapping Metabolic Drivers of Disease using Chemoproteomic and Metabolomic Platforms
218A.description:
We will discuss current research in the following three areas: 1) mapping metabolic drivers of human diseases using
chemoproteomic and metabolomic platforms; 2) expanding the druggable proteome through mapping and pharmacologically interrogating proteome-wide
hyper-reactive and ligandable hotspots; 3) mapping proteome-wide targets of environmental and pharmaceutical chemicals towards understanding novel
toxicological mechanisms.

90A.title: Freshman Seminars: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
90A.description: The Berkeley Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Berkeley Seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester.

218X.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Chemical Reactions of Metabolism
218X.description: Define how metabolic reactions function in the context of the cellular system in order to elucidate the so-called design principles of metabolic function.

160.title: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology
160.description: Comprehensive introductory survey of cellular and molecular neuroscience, including cellular neurophysiology, ion channel function, synaptic function and plasticity, sensory transduction, and brain development.  Includes introduction to molecular basis of neurological disease.  Analysis from the level of molecules to cells to simple circuits.

239O.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Cancer Biology
239O.description: Inheritance, chromatin structure, gene expression, and the organization of chromosomes in the nucleus.

218C.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Synthetic Biology and Cellular Enzymology
218C.description: Synthetic biology, metabolic engineering, systems biology, enzyme mechanism, and gene discovery.

219S.title: Research Review in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology: Structural Biology of Signaling and Replication
219S.description: Mechanisms and structure in DNA replication and eukaryotic cell signaling.

239K.title: Research Review in Cell and Developmental Biology: Secretion and Cell Membrane Assembly
239K.description: Cell surface growth with emphasis on the unicellular eukaryote S. cerevisiae.

249O.title: Research Review in Genetics and Development: Genome Sequences
249O.description: Biochemistry, cancer biology and virology, cell biology, computational biology, genetics, microbiology, molecular and cell physiology.

269E.title: Molecular and Biophysical Neuroscience
269E.description: Review of research in molecular and biophysical aspects of sensory transduction and electrical signaling in the nervous system.

C112.title: General Microbiology
C112.description: This course will explore the molecular bases for physiological and biochemical diversity among members of the two major domains, Bacteria and Archaea. The ecological significance and evolutionary origins of this diversity will be discussed. Molecular, genetic, and structure-function analyses of microbial cell cycles, adaptive responses, metabolic capability, and macromolecular syntheses will be emphasized.

259M.title: Research Review in Immunology and Pathogenesis: Innate Immunity and Innate Control of Adaptive Immunity
259M.description: Innate immunity and innate control of adaptive immunity.
